skill.name: reasoning-inductive
skill.description: Extract patterns and generalizations from multiple observations. Use when detecting recurring themes, building predictive rules, or identifying systemic behaviors from accumulated data. Produces validated patterns with confidence bounds and exception handling.
skill.summary: Extract patterns and generalizations from multiple observations. Use when detecting recurring themes...
skill.author: BellaBe

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation file containing only markdown and YAML frontmatter. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or file system operations. This is a knowledge-base skill describing inductive reasoning methodology.

content.value_statement: When you need to detect recurring themes across multiple observations, build predictive rules from experience, or identify systemic behaviors. This skill produces validated patterns with confidence bounds and explicit exception handling.
actual_capabilities: Detect patterns across multiple observations with quantified strength metrics
Generate validated generalizations with confidence bounds
Identify exceptions and boundary conditions for learned rules
Support hypothesis generation from accumulated data
Apply statistical validation including holdout testing and temporal stability checks
limitations: Requires minimum 5 observations for meaningful pattern detection
Confidence depends on data completeness and recency
Cannot transfer patterns between different domains without adaptation

use_cases.title: Discover sales patterns
use_cases.description: Analyze recurring themes across deal data to forecast outcomes and identify risk factors

use_cases.title: Find user behavior trends
use_cases.description: Detect usage patterns from accumulated product data to inform feature prioritization

use_cases.title: Build empirical rules
use_cases.description: Form generalizations from experimental observations with quantified confidence

prompt_templates.title: Basic pattern scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Use inductive reasoning to analyze these observations. Identify all patterns, calculate confidence bounds, and list exceptions.

prompt_templates.title: With data quality
prompt_templates.prompt: Run inductive analysis on this dataset. Report pattern strength, sample size adequacy, and data quality scores for each finding.

prompt_templates.title: With validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply inductive reasoning with holdout validation. Show how patterns perform on test data and flag any overfitting concerns.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-source synthesis
prompt_templates.prompt: Synthesize patterns across multiple data sources. Identify common themes, conflicts, and build unified generalizations with scoped applicability.

output_examples.input: Analyze these 15 customer support tickets that escalated to engineering
output: Pattern detected (78% confidence): Escalations cluster around configuration issues
Rule formed: Tickets mentioning 'setup' or 'integration' escalate 4x more often
Exceptions: 2 tickets about genuine bugs did not follow this pattern
Recommendation: Create self-service setup guides to reduce escalations by estimated 60%

best_practices: Collect at least 10 observations before drawing actionable conclusions
Include both successes and failures to avoid survivorship bias
Re-validate patterns every 6 months as processes change
Document the mechanism behind each pattern, not just correlation
anti_patterns: Acting on patterns from fewer than 5 observations
Promoting correlation to causation without mechanism testing
Ignoring exceptions or treating them as noise
Applying patterns outside their documented domain

faq.question: How many observations do I need?
faq.answer: Minimum 5 for exploratory patterns. Aim for 10+ for actionable conclusions. 21+ for high confidence.

faq.question: What data formats work best?
faq.answer: Structured data with consistent attributes works best. Semi-structured notes can work if attributes are extractable.

faq.question: Does this skill access my files?
faq.answer: No. This is a reasoning framework. You provide observations as input; nothing is read from disk.

faq.question: How is this different from abductive reasoning?
faq.answer: Abductive explains one observation. Inductive builds rules from many observations. Use abductive for diagnosis, inductive for pattern discovery.

faq.question: Can I combine this with other reasoning skills?
faq.answer: Yes. Use inductive to find patterns, then abductive to explain mechanisms, then causal to test interventions.

faq.question: What confidence level is actionable?
faq.answer: 0.70+ is typically actionable for business decisions. Higher stakes decisions may require 0.85+ with causal validation.
